format.description: Design tokens represent fundamental decisions of a design language, specifying their intended usage with their semantic naming in a predictable and clear way. For example, $color-text-link-destructive is used for displaying link text that communicates an action is destructive. Using the appropriate token ensures that all destructive actions are styled consistently, appearing as red text in this case. Tokens are named semantically to specify their intended usage. The format of a design token name is: $type-category-instance-variant-state. Pieces of the name structure can be omitted if they're not relevant. There may be cases where simply a $type-instance makes the most sense, such as $space-2.

$type.description: Types are the high-level, foundational styles the token will be applied to. (Only dealing with colors in this spec, as the other types are more straightforward.)

$category.description: Categories are the UI entities the token will be applied to.

value.description: Use for elements above primary content but below floating elements, such as underlays behind modals and popovers.
Use for the main content area of a module or component.
Use for communicating brand reinforcement on elements.
Use for communicating critical information, such as errors.
Use for decorative purposes only when no semantic meaning is applicable.
Use for communicating information that encourages exploration or discovery within the interface, such as something new or something changed.
Use for communicating information, something in-progress, or providing feedback to the user.
Use for form elements, such as text fields, checkboxes, and radio buttons.
Use for communicating information that users can actively engage with.
Use for communicating information that is not intended to stand out or draw much attention.
Use to communicate information that is most essential and attention grabbing while connecting to the core brand, such as key interactive elements.
Use to communicate information that supports or complements visual elements that are not as prominent as the primary elements but connect tothe core brand.
Use to communicate a favorable outcome.
Use for communicating caution, such as 'at risk' statuses.

$instance.description: Instances are the occurrences in which the token might be used to express that instance in the UI.

value.description: Use for variations on shadows that face inward.
Use for variations of colors on bold or inverse backgrounds.

$variant.description: The variant of an instance token.

$state.description: State in which the token should be used.
